case_name: Kanti Prasad Jayshankar Yagnik v. Purshottamdass Ranchoddas Patel

facts.text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated December 5, 1967 of the Gujarat High Court in Election Petition No. 3 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 979 of 1968. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated December 5, 1967 of the Gujarat High Court in Election Petition No. 3 of 1967.

facts.text: The poll for the election was taken on February 21, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Before we set out the impugned passages from the speeches we may give a few preliminary facts. The poll for the election was taken on February 21, 1967, and the result of the election declared on February 22, 1967.

facts.text: The result of the election declared on February 22, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The poll for the election was taken on February 21, 1967, and the result of the election declared on February 22, 1967. Purshottamdass Ranchoddas Patel, the petitioner in the High Court and respondent before us, secured 16,159 votes whereas the appellantsecured 23,055 votes.

facts.text: Purshottamdass Ranchoddas Patel secured 16,159 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Purshottamdass Ranchoddas Patel, the petitioner in the High Court and respondent before us, secured 16,159 votes whereas the appellantsecured 23,055 votes. The other candidates, who were respondents to the petition secured 720 votes, 1,017 votes and 454 votes, respectively.

facts.text: Appellant secured 23,055 votes.

anchor.surface_text: whereas the appellantsecured 23,055 votes. The other candidates, who were respondents to the petition secured 720 votes, 1,017 votes and 454 votes, respectively. The petition out of the which this. ,appeal arises was filed on April 5, 1967

facts.text: The petition was filed on April 5, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The petition out of the which this. ,appeal arises was filed on April 5, 1967, and the petitioner prayed for the relief that the election of the appellant be declared void and further prayed that he be declared duly elected to the Assembly

facts.text: Appellant elected to Gujarat State Assembly from Mehsana State Assembly Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: setting aside the election of Kanti Prasad Jayshankar Yagnik, appellant before us, to the Gujarat State Assembly from Mehsana State Assembly Constituency under s. 123 2 , s. 123 3  and s. 100 1  b  of the Representation of the People Act

facts.text: Public meetings of Shri Shambhu Maharaj arranged on February 18, 1967 at various villages in Mehsana Assembly constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Various grounds were urged in the petition but we need only deal with the ground that the appellant and his agents arranged public meetings of Shri Shambhu Maharaj on February 18, 1967, at various villages which were part of the Mehsana Assembly companystituency

facts.text: Shambhu Maharaj made speeches appealing to vote for appellant on ground of religion, caste, and community.

anchor.surface_text: and Shambhu Maharaj made a systematic appeal in his speeches to a large section of the electors to vote for the appellant on ground of religion, caste, and companymunity, and the electors were told that it would be an irreligious act to vote for the petitioner

facts.text: High Court held certain speeches by Shambhu Maharaj amounted to corrupt practices under ss. 123(2) and 123(3).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that certain speeches made by Shambhu Maharaj, with the companysent of the appellant, amounted to companyrupt practices within the meaning of ss. 123 2  and 123 3  of the Act.

facts.text: Speech by Shambhu Maharaj at village Motidav on February 18, 1967, appellant present.

anchor.surface_text: As an example we may companysider the evidence of P.W. 7, who testified regarding the speech, Ex. J., delivered at village Motidav. He stated that Shambhu Maharaj addressed the meeting at Motidav at about 5.30 p.m. on February 18, 1967, and the appellant was present at that meeting

facts.text: Petition sought to prove speeches by police reports.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner sought to prove the speeches by producing members of the Police Force, as witnesses, who had under instructions of Government taken down numberes of the, speeches and reported them to their officers.

facts.text: High Court relied on police reports as correctly recorded.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on the reports of these members of the Police Force and held that their reports were companyrectly recorded and fairly represented the speeches made by Shambhu Maharaj.

facts.text: Appellant contends police reports not admissible under Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel,for the appellant, Mr. S. T. Desai, company- tends, first, that the reports made by the members of the Police Force are number admissible in evidence, and secondly, that in the circumstances of the case numberweight should be attached to these reports.

facts.text: Supreme Court held reports admissible under s. 160 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that on the facts the report, Ex. J., was properly used under s. 160 of the Indian Evidence Act. The question of the weight to be attached to the various reports of the speeches is another matter and we will deal with the question presently.

facts.text: Speech at Kherwa after midnight February 18, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The following four passages in Ex. K, a speech delivered by Shambhu Maharaj at Kherwa after midnight of February 18, 1967, were objected to

facts.text: High Court held passage in Ex. K last passage constitutes corrupt practice under s. 123(3) appeal on caste.

anchor.surface_text: The last passage in Ex. K clearly fell within the mischief of s. 123 3 . The High Court in this companynection observed .lm15 The reference to Vijaykumarbhai is to Vijaykumar Trivedi, who was a Brahmin and was a minister

facts.text: Appellant is Brahmin, appeal to vote for him to have Brahmin minister.

anchor.surface_text: asking the people to vote for the first respondent because he was a Brahmin by caste. It has been stated as a categorical statement that there must be at least one Minister, who was a Brahmin.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees High Court correct on inference of caste appeal in Ex. K.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Court is companyrect in drawing the inference that Shambhu Maharaj was asking his voters to, vote for the first respondent, because he was a Brahmin.

facts.text: Passages in Ex. P constitute corrupt practice under s. 123(2).

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the first and the third passages, read together, companystitute an attempt to induce the electors to believe that they would become objects of divine displeasure if they voted for the Congress

facts.text: Supreme Court finds consent of appellant to speeches.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that there is numberforce in this companytention. The High Court observed As shown in the handbill setting out the pro- gramme, the manuscript of which was written out by the first respondent himself

facts.text: Appellant present at meetings at MotiDav, Kherwa and Dangerwa.

anchor.surface_text: To my mind, therefore, it is clear that the first respondent had accompanied Shambhu Maharaj and was present in each of the meetings at MotiDav, Kherwa and Dangerwa when Shambhu Maharaj delivered speeches at these three villages

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In-the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Hegde J. agrees statements in Exh. P amount to corrupt practice under s. 123(2) with consent.

anchor.surface_text: Hegde, J. I agree that the statements companytained in Exh. P amount to a companyrupt practice under s. 123 2  of the Representation of the People Act and also agree that those statements were made with the companysent of the returned candidate.

facts.text: Petitioner is a Patidar.

anchor.surface_text: I may point out that so far as the petitioner is companycerned, the petitioner is a Patidar and it is in the companytext of this background that an appeal is made in the name of caste of the first respondent

issues.text: Whether the reports made by the members of the Police Force are admissible in evidence under Sections 159 and 160 of the Indian Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant, Mr. S. T. Desai, contends, first, that the reports made by the members of the Police Force are not admissible in evidence, and secondly, that in the circumstances of the case no weight should be attached to these reports. We may first deal with the question of the admissibility of, the evidence before we set out the speeches. The learned counsel contends that under the Indian Evidence Act written reports of speeches can only be used in two ways one, to refresh a witnesss memory under S. 159, and secondly, under S. 160 after satisfying two conditions

issues.text: Whether it is necessary for a witness to specifically state that he has no specific recollection and is sure facts were correctly recorded before using document under s.160 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that it is not necessary that a witness should specifically state that he has no specific recollection of the facts and that he is sure that the facts were correctly recorded in the document, before the document can be used under s. 160. It is enough if it appears from his evidence that these conditions are established.

issues.text: Whether weight should be attached to the police reports of the speeches

anchor.surface_text: secondly, that in the circumstances of the case no weight should be attached to these reports.

issues.text: Whether the third passage in Ex. J constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(3) RP Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not find the first two passages to constitute corrupt practices. The third passage was held by the High Court to constitute corrupt practice on the ground that though there is no proof that Shankaracharya had any religious following as such in this particular constituency...

issues.text: Whether passages 1 and 2 in Ex. K constitute corrupt practice under s.123(2) proviso (a)(ii) RP Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held the first two passages read together to constitute corrupt practice on the ground that they amounted to interference with the free exercise of the electoral right of voters by holding out threats of divine displeasure and spiritual censure... This, in our view, cannot amount to constitute corrupt practice within s. 123(2) proviso (a)(ii)

issues.text: Whether the last passage in Ex. K constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(3) RP Act (appeal on ground of caste - Brahmin minister)

anchor.surface_text: The last passage in Ex. K clearly fell within the mischief of s. 123(3). ...it is clear that in this particular passage an appeal was being made to the electors to cast their votes for the first respondent because the first respondent is a Brahmin.

issues.text: Whether passages 1 and 3 in Ex. P constitute corrupt practice under s.123(2) RP Act

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the first and the third passages, read together, constitute an attempt to induce the electors to believe that they would become objects of divine displeasure if they voted for the Congress...

issues.text: Whether the corrupt practices were committed with the consent of the returned candidate

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel further contends that the appellants consent to these speeches had not been proved. We agree with the High Court that there is no force in this contention.

issues.text: Whether for s.123(2) RP Act, the statement must be made by a religious head of the majority of electors

anchor.surface_text: I am unable to agree that before a statement can be considered as an attempt to induce an elector to believe that he will be rendered an object of spiritual censure if he acts in a particular manner that statement must have been made by a person who is a religious head

issues.text: Whether appeal for Brahmin minister in Ex. K is appeal on ground of caste under s.123(3)

anchor.surface_text: I am unable to agree that the appeal to vote in Exh. K for the appellant on the ground that he is likely to be a Minister as according to Shambhu Maharaj there should be at least one Brahmin Minister in the cabinet is an appeal to vote on the ground of the appellants caste.

arguments.claim: Ex. J admissible under s.160 Evidence Act

holdings.text: The reports made by the members of the Police Force are admissible in evidence under s. 160 of the Indian Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that on the facts the report, Ex. J., was properly used under s. 160 of the Indian Evidence Act. The question of the weight to be attached to the various reports of the speeches is another matter and we will deal with the question presently.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditions under s.160 satisfied as implied from witness evidence without need for explicit statement; witness wrote contemporaneously from notes.

holdings.text: It is not necessary for a witness to specifically state no specific recollection and surety of correct recording before using document under s.160 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that it is not necessary that a witness should specifically state that he has no specific recollection of the facts and that he is sure that the facts were correctly recorded in the document, before the document can be used under s. 160.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enough if conditions appear from evidence; lapse of time implies no recollection; court assesses position to record correctly.

holdings.text: Weight should be attached to the police reports of the speeches as credible.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the conclusions arrived at by the High Court. It is true that the exact words were not taken down by the various police constables, but the similarity of approach, appeal and the attack on the Congress is remarkable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common topics, language, approach in independent reports; substance correctly reproduced despite not verbatim.

holdings.text: The third passage in Ex. J does not constitute corrupt practice under s.123(3) RP Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the High Court in this respect. The decision of this Court in Ram Dial v. Sant Lal is clearly distinguishable because there it was held by this Court that Shri Sat Guru wielded great local influence

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof Jagadguru wielded influence over majority electors; distinguishable from precedent; no bar on appealing not to vote Congress in name of religion.

holdings.text: Passages 1 and 2 in Ex. K do not constitute corrupt practice under s.123(2) proviso (a)(ii) RP Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that this is not a fair reading of these two passages. Cow slaughter is not mentioned in these passages except to say that cow slaughter is banned in Gujarat. The causal relationship, if any, exists between slaughter

holdings.reasoning_summary: No causal link to divine displeasure; mere description of party as irreligious or linking to calamities not barred by proviso.

holdings.text: The last passage in Ex. K constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(3) RP Act.

anchor.surface_text: The last passage in Ex. K clearly fell within the mischief of s. 123(3). The High Court in this connection observed The reference to Vijaykumarbhai is to Vijaykumar Trivedi, who was a Brahmin and was a minister

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear appeal to vote for candidate as Brahmin to ensure Brahmin minister; categorical statement on caste ground.

holdings.text: Passages 1 and 3 in Ex. P constitute corrupt practice under s.123(2) RP Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the first and the third passages, read together, constitute an attempt to induce the electors to believe that they would become objects of divine displeasure if they voted for the Congress

holdings.reasoning_summary: Induces belief in divine displeasure for voting Congress due to cow slaughter; follows precedent on veneration of cow and gohatya sin.

holdings.text: The corrupt practices were committed with the consent of the returned candidate.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel further contends that the appellants consent to these speeches had not been proved. We agree with the High Court that there is no force in this contention. The High Court observed As shown in the handbill

holdings.reasoning_summary: Candidate arranged meetings, wrote handbill, present at speeches, no dissociation; aids election.

holdings.text: For s.123(2) RP Act, the statement need not be made by a religious head of the majority of electors.

anchor.surface_text: Hegde, J. I agree that the statements contained in Exh. P amount to a corrupt practice under s. 123(2) of the Representation of the People Act and also agree that those statements were made with the consent of the returned candidate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to even single elector; depends on statement nature, speaker, audience; no justification to limit scope.

holdings.text: Appeal for Brahmin minister in Ex. K is not appeal on ground of caste under s.123(3).

anchor.surface_text: I am unable to agree that the appeal to vote in Exh. K for the appellant on the ground that he is likely to be a Minister as according to Shambhu Maharaj there should be at least one Brahmin Minister in the cabinet

holdings.reasoning_summary: Communal/regional representation common; caste incidental, not direct appeal on caste ground.

anchor.surface_text: The position seems to be the same in some States in U.S.A., vide Wigmore on Evidence Third Edition Vol. III pp. 97- 98, extracted below 1871, Per Curiam in Moots v. State, 21 Oh. St. 653 The entry in the book and the oath of the witness supplement each other. The book was really a part of the oath, and therefore admissible with it in evidence.

precedents.cited_proposition: The entry in the book and the oath of the witness supplement each other. The book was really a part of the oath, and therefore admissible with it in evidence.
precedents.cited_holding: The entry in the book and the oath of the witness supplement each other.

anchor.surface_text: 1879, Earl, J., in Howard v. McDonough 77 Y. 592 After the witness has testified, the memorandum which he has used may be put in evidence,-not as proving anything of itself, but as a detailed statement of the items testified to by the witness.

precedents.cited_proposition: After the witness has testified, the memorandum which he has used may be put in evidence, not as proving anything of itself, but as a detailed statement of the items testified to by the witness.

anchor.surface_text: 1882, Cooley, J., in Mason v. Phelps, 48 Mich. 126, 11 N.W. 413, 837 After she had testified that she knew it to be correct, she might have read the entries or repeated them as her evidence.

precedents.cited_proposition: After she had testified that she knew it to be correct, she might have read the entries or repeated them as her evidence. Showing the book was no more than this.

anchor.surface_text: 1886, Smith, C.J., in Bryan v. Moring, 94 C. 687 The memorandum thus supported and identified becomes part of the testimony of the witness, just as if without it the witness had orally repeated the words from memory.

precedents.cited_proposition: The memorandum thus supported and identified becomes part of the testimony of the witness, just as if without it the witness had orally repeated the words from memory.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel relied on the dissenting judgment of Sankaran-Nair, J., in Mylapore Krishnasami v. Emperor 1 where he observed If therefore the constable has number recorded correctly the words used by the speaker but only his impression, then the numberes would be inadmissible under section 160

precedents.cited_proposition: If the constable has not recorded correctly the words used by the speaker but only his impression, then the notes would be inadmissible under section 160 of the Indian Evidence Act to prove the words used. They may be admissible to prove the impression created in the mind of the constable.

precedents.citation: Mohansingh Laxmansingh v. Bhanwarlal Rajmal Nahata 2 A.I.R. 1964 M.P. 137,146

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel also referred to the decision of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Mohansingh Laxmansingh v. Bhanwarlal Rajmal Nahata 2 . The High Court seems to have held that on the facts, the statements prepared by the witness in that case did number become primary evidence

precedents.case_name: Mohansingh Laxmansingh v. Bhanwarlal Rajmal Nahata
precedents.cited_proposition: The notes were taken down for a particular purpose, to wit, for an election petition, and raise a reasonable suspicion that what the witness recorded was number a correct record of the speech.
precedents.cited_holding: Statements prepared by witness did not become primary evidence of the speech and cannot be used as such.

precedents.citation: Sodhi Pindi Das v. Emperor 1 A.I.R. 1938 Lah. 629

anchor.surface_text: Blacker, J. in Sodhi Pindi Das v. Emperor 1 held, relying on Jagan Nath v. Emperor 2 that it is essential that the witness must state orally before the Court that although he had numberspecific recollection of the facts themselves, he was sure that the facts were correctly recorded

precedents.cited_proposition: It is essential that the witness must state orally before the Court that although he had no specific recollection of the facts themselves, he was sure that the facts were correctly recorded in the document.

precedents.citation: Jagan Nath v. Emperor 2 I.L.R. 1944 Mad. 11

anchor.surface_text: Blacker, J. in Sodhi Pindi Das v. Emperor 1 held, relying on Jagan Nath v. Emperor 2 that it is essential that the witness must state orally before the Court that although he had numberspecific recollection of the facts themselves, he was sure that the facts were companyrectly recorded

precedents.cited_proposition: Witness must state orally no specific recollection and sure facts correctly recorded.

precedents.citation: Public Prosecutor v. Venkatarama Naidu 3 A.I.R. 1932 Lah. 7

anchor.surface_text: In Public Prosecutor v. Venkatarama Naidu 3 Mockett, J., rightly dissented from the judgment of the Lahore High Court in Sodhi Pindi Das v. Emperor 1 . In England the Law of Evidence has been changed and many of such documents made directly admissible see Phipson on Evidence,

precedents.cited_proposition: Dissented from the judgment requiring express oral statement by witness for use under s.160.

anchor.surface_text: Mockett, J., rightly dissented from the judgment of the Lahore High Court in Sodhi Pindi Das v. Emperor 1 . In England the Law of Evidence has been changed and many of such documents made directly admissible  see Phipson on Evidence, Tenth Edition, Ch. 22 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Judgment dissented from regarding requirement of express statement by witness.

precedents.citation: Ram Dial v. Sant Lal 1 1959 Supp. 2 S. C. R. 748

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the High Court in this respect. The decision of this Court in Ram Dial v. Sant Lal 1 is clearly distinguishable because there it was held by this Court that Shri Sat Guru wielded great local influence among the large number of Namdharis who were voters

precedents.cited_proposition: Shri Sat Guru wielded great local influence among the large number of Namdharis who were voters in the Sirsa constituency.
precedents.cited_holding: Religious leader wielding great local influence constitutes corrupt practice when directive disregarded.

precedents.citation: Narbada Prasad v. Chhagan Lal 1 1969 1 S.C.R. 499

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the first and the third passages, read together, constitute an attempt to induce the electors to believe that they would become objects of divine displeasure if they voted for the Congress and thereby allowed cow slaughter to be continued. Hidayatullah, C.J., in Narbada Prasad v.

precedents.cited_proposition: Cow is venerated in our country by the vast majority of the people and that they believe not only in its utility but its holiness. It is also believed that one of the cardinal sins is that of gohatya. Therefore, it is quite obvious that to remind the voters that they would be committing the sin of gohatya would be to remind them that they would be objects of divine displeasure or spiritual censure.
precedents.cited_holding: Reminding voters they would be committing the sin of gohatya would induce belief of divine displeasure or spiritual censure.
